findings.title: ELFM - Exceeds Fees Limit
findings.description: The contract owner has the authority to increase over the allowed limit of 25%. The owner may take advantage of it by calling the fee setter functions with a high value. As a result, the total fees will sum up to 30%.

findings.title: PLE - Potential Locked Ether
findings.description: During the swap method, the contract calculates the swapped ETH by subtracting the ethForLottery. If the contract receives ETH from an external address, these ETH are not calculated by the swap method. As a result, they will be locked in the contract forever.

findings.title: PTRP - Potential Transfer Revert Propagation
findings.description: The contract sends funds to a `marketingAddress` as part of the transfer flow, which can either be a wallet address or a contract. If the address belongs to a contract, it may revert from incoming payment, propagating the error to the token's contract and reverting the transfer.

findings.title: RV - Randomization Vulnerability
findings.description: The contract uses an on-chain technique to determine random numbers, which can be predicted due to the deterministic blockchain runtime environment.

findings.title: PVC - Price Volatility Concern
findings.description: The contract accumulates tokens from taxes to swap them for ETH, but if `numTokensSellToAddToLiquidity` is set to a big number, it may trigger a huge token swap, leading to significant price volatility due to the token's highly volatile price.

findings.title: IDI - Immutable Declaration Improvement
findings.description: The contract declares state variables that are initialized once in the constructor and are not modified afterwards. Declaring these variables as immutable can save gas by allowing the Solidity compiler to make certain optimizations.

findings.title: L04 - Conformance to Solidity Naming Conventions
findings.description: The code does not adhere to the Solidity naming conventions, which can negatively impact readability and maintainability.

findings.title: L07 - Missing Events Arithmetic
findings.description: Events are a way to record and log information about changes or actions that occur within a contract. They are often used to notify external parties or clients about events that have occurred within the contract, such as the transfer of tokens or the completion of a task.

findings.title: L09 - Dead Code Elimination
findings.description: Dead code can make a contract more difficult to understand and maintain, and can also increase the size of the contract and the cost of deploying and interacting with it.

findings.title: L16 - Validate Variable Setters
findings.description: The contract performs operations on variables configured by user-supplied input without proper checks for zero values, leading to potential problems during execution.

findings.title: L17 - Usage of Solidity Assembly
findings.description: Using assembly can be useful for optimizing code, but it can also be error-prone.
